p: Antibacterial activities of the essential oils from aerial parts and from roots of C. cernuum were tested against the standard bacterial lines, both Gram-positive ( Staphylococcus aureus, Enterococcus faecalis) and Gram-negative ( Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Serratia marcescens, Acinetobacter baumanii). Thymol, a monoterpenoid being found in numerous essential oils and having well-documented antimicrobial activity [ 17], was used as a reference compound. In general, the essential oil distilled from the aerial parts of C. cernuum demonstrated better bacteriostatic activity than that obtained from roots (see Table 2). A. baumanii ATCC 19606 and S. aureus ATCC 29213 were the most susceptible to both the examined essential oils and the thymol solution. Minimal inhibitory concentrations (MICs) against S. aureus were determined as 15.6 and 62.5 µL/mL for essential oils from C. cernuum aerial parts and roots, respectively. Growth of S. marcescens ATCC 13880 was inhibited only by the highest concentrations of the essential oils tested (MIC ≥ 250 µL/mL).
